ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Take this if you want to read a lot of great material and discuss it in-depth! Be prepared for a semester centering around exile-- if you don't want to talk about it every class for five months, then this is probably not the course for you. Professor Gosselink is a wonderful source of help in terms of helping you improve your writing skills, and her classes are well-led. Just expect a moderate (but overall enjoyable) work load.
Good intro course; teaches how to think and write critically in the context of the literature of exile. Good intro to the library and the process of research.

This is very much like a high school English class with a faster pace. The books on the syllabus are very good and it's a low-pressure seminar environment which helps to build confidence for later classes at Yale. That said, I found the course less-enriching than I would've hoped; I don't think my writing improved. This is a good course if you are looking for a non-judgmental seminar environment, but it is very difficult to get high marks and you won't actually learn very much.
Highly recommend, good contrast to other courses.
